verse: Then Solomon began to build the ·Temple [house] of the Lord in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah [Gen. 22:2]. This was where the Lord had appeared to David, Solomon’s father. Solomon built the ·Temple [house] on the place David had prepared on the threshing floor of ·Araunah [or Ornan; 1 Chr. 21:15, 18–28] the Jebusite.
Solomon began building in the ·second month [or second day of the second month; midspring] of the fourth year ·he ruled Israel [of his reign].

Solomon used ·these measurements [or this foundation] for building the ·Temple [house] of God. It was ·ninety feet [sixty cubits] long and ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] wide, using the old ·measurement [standard].

The ·porch [portico; vestibule; entry room] in front of the main ·room [hall] of the ·Temple [house] was ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] long and ·thirty feet [twenty cubits; or one hundred twenty cubits] high.

He put panels of ·pine [cypress; juniper; evergreens] on the walls of the ·main room [main hall; nave] and ·covered [overlaid] them with ·pure [fine] gold. Then he ·put [decorated/ornamented it with] designs of palm trees and chains in the gold.
He ·decorated [adorned] the ·Temple [house] with ·gems [precious stones] and gold from Parvaim.
He ·put [overlaid] gold on the ·Temple’s [house’s] ceiling beams, ·doorposts [thresholds], walls, and doors, and he carved ·creatures with wings [cherubim] on the walls.

Then he made the ·Most Holy Place [Holy of Holies]. It was ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] long and ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] wide, ·as wide as [corresponding to the width of] the ·Temple [house]. He ·covered [overlaid] its walls with ·about forty-six thousand pounds [six hundred talents] of ·pure [fine] gold.
The gold nails weighed ·over a pound [fifty shekels]. He also ·covered [overlaid] the upper rooms with gold.
He ·made [sculpted; modeled] two ·creatures with wings [cherubim] for the ·Most Holy Place [Holy of Holies] and ·covered [overlaid] them with gold.

The wings of the ·gold creatures [cherubim] were ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] across. One wing of one creature was ·seven and one-half feet [five cubits] long and touched the ·Temple [house] wall. The creature’s other wing was also ·seven and one-half feet [five cubits] long, and it touched a wing of the second ·creature [cherub].

One wing of the second creature touched the other side of the room and was also ·seven and one-half feet [five cubits] long. The second creature’s other wing touched the first creature’s wing, and it was also ·seven and one-half feet [five cubits] long.
Together, the creatures’ wings were ·thirty feet [twenty cubits] across. The creatures stood on their feet, facing the ·main room [main hall; nave].

He made the ·curtain [veil] of ·blue [violet], purple, and ·red thread [crimson cloth/yarn], and ·expensive [fine] linen, and he ·put [worked; embroidered] designs of ·creatures with wings [cherubim] in it.

header: The Pillars and Furnishings for the Temple(B)

verse: He made two pillars to stand in front of the ·Temple [house]. They were ·about fifty-two feet [thirty-five cubits; possibly the combined length of the two] tall, and the capital on top of each pillar was over ·seven feet [five cubits] tall.
He made ·a net of [interwoven] chains and put them on the tops of the pillars. He made a hundred pomegranates and put them on the chains.

Then he put the pillars up in front of the Temple. One pillar stood on the ·south [right] side, the other on the ·north [left]. He named the ·south [right] pillar Jachin [“he establishes”] and the ·north [left] pillar Boaz [“in him is strength”].
